_ui_color_palette.title: @:work._ui_color_palette.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_ui_color_palette.shortDescription: Accessible color palettes with consistant lightness with Figma
_ui_color_palette.description: Figma is an UX tool, using diagrams to build user experiences, interfaces, prototypes, and illustrations‚Ä¶ The tool can be extended with a plugin system. Figma tends to be the leader of UX tools market because of its inclusive and powerful business model. So, Figma is still the most exciting tool. By reading this article (Accessible Palette: stop using HSL for color systems), I noticed there is not any plugin on Figma to help to build accessible color systems for UI. The opportunity is to develop a tool to create, edit and deploy color palettes.

misc.objectives: Creating UI color palettes with consistant lightness and contrast, Updating and deploy colors with ease to the team library
misc.roles: Developing the scripts to create/edit color palette (React)

challenge.title: Make UI color palettes with the LCH color model
challenge.paragraph-1: The plugin uses the LCH (Lightness-Chroma-Hue) model to generate colors according to the chosen lightness scale. The model LCH is relevant to make colors compliant with the¬†WCAG standards.
challenge.paragraph-2: It works like the HSL (Hue-Saturation-Lightness) color model. The HSL is simple to use to build a color system, because the lightness can just be changed to create variants. The LCH too, but the Chroma, and the Hue are automatically adjusted to keep the colors within the¬†sRGB gamut.

part-1.title: How does it work?
part-1.caption-1: The workflow is quite simple: Select some starting colors on the canvas, edit the lightness scale, then create the color palette.
part-1.caption-2: Then, edit the lightness scale (it will tweak the colors) and add them to the local styles.
part-1.caption-3: Finally, tweak the lightness scale and update the local styles to maintain the color system with ease.

takeaway-1.description: If you want to test the plugin, you can install it on your Figma account from the plugin page.

takeaway-2.description: UI Color Palette is an open-source project. You can take a glance at the source code on Github.

_jeprendsquoi.title: @:work._jeprendsquoi.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_jeprendsquoi.description: I often go at the market, to buy some fresh and local food. For decades, my parents taught me consume local food is the best way to feed, because the local economy is stimulated and the carbon footprint is lower. So, avoiding supermarket and co. is a leitmotiv. However, the local market reveals its own limits because of some absurdities: find some cherries in winter (17‚Ç¨ a kilogram), some tomatoes or melons on november. The bitter conclusion is simple: strict seasonality is not yet a standard.

misc.objectives: Checking a product's seasonality (fruits and vegetable), Encouraging people to contribute to the product's seasonality database
misc.roles: Building and maintaining the database, Creating a brand: jeprendsquoi (the daily helper), Designing a mobile companion to find the right information insitu (supermarket & market), Developing a mobile app with a no-code solution

challenge.title: The problem of non-seasonal food
challenge.paragraph-1: A non-seasonal fruit or vegetable comes from:
challenge.paragraph-2:
• Abroad, in a country where the cultivation is seasonal or locally unavailable
  • Cultivated in a greenhouse
challenge.paragraph-3: Abroad, the carbon footprint is high because of the transportation: by boat or plane. And yet, cultivate inside a greenhouse has a more expensive carbon footprint. Indeed, a greenhouse keeps a non-stop heat to simulate the season temperature, and make the cultivation grow. That is why we can see some tomatoes on november, they grow in a greenhouse in Brittany.

part-1.title: A first prototype to solve the problem
part-1.paragraph-1: There are a couple of tools to make some quick database. No-code is an interesting philosophy to build and test quickly something. Airtable has been chosen because its databases can use different visual representations. The grid was the most relevant view to retrieve a vegetable or a fruit and consult its data.
part-1.paragraph-2: The limitation of this representation is the device context. Indeed, the main use case takes place outside, at the market or the supermarket. People are not used to bring their laptop to the supermarket. So, this solution is not viable for a real usage on the ground.
part-1.paragraph-3: Nevertheless, people might take their smartphone! And Notion can be consulted with the native app or via a shared URL. The access point is a bit risky because people might loose the shared URL or their Notion account. So, make a mobile app should be safer.
part-1.caption-1: The grid representation is clear enough to help user to retrieve the product he is looking for. Besides, Airtable provides a discrete search feature to help a bit more. The fruits and vegetables grid views have been divided into two databases in the first instance. Consult the fruits and vegetables databases.
part-1.caption-2: Notion has merged the two Airtable databases into one. Notion operates in the same way and the reason of this migration is simple: Notion is my all-in-one digital workplace. Consult the Fruits and Vegetables database.

part-2.title: Make the data alive and retrievable
part-2.paragraph-1: The data are ready on Notion and can be represented on a mobile app as an interactive list with some additional features: filter, search, expand, share, and contribute. The app has been built with Bravo Studio, a no-code mobile app builder, that gathers API calls and Figma templates.
part-2.paragraph-2: The brand has been created and developed around a simple question: What do I take? A question we ask at the supermarket. The purpose is to help people make environmentally friendly choices.
part-2.caption-1: The list of fruits and vegetables is displayed as the main section. The list can be filtered by season.
part-2.caption-2: The search feature allows user to find a specific product
part-2.caption-3: The detailed page gives user the months of consumption and some additional information
part-2.caption-4: Every user can contribute to the list, just by filling the form. A moderation step is required before publishing.
part-2.caption-5: The templates are edited on Figma. Those pages are composed with placeholders, that will be replaced and duplicated thanks to API calls.
part-2.caption-6: The brand has been created and developed around a simple question: What do I take? A question we ask at the supermarket. The purpose is to help people make environmentally friendly choices.
part-2.caption-7: This looping animation is the mobile app loader when the page is not loaded yet.
part-2.caption-8: On the splash screen, the logotype fades in to introduce the app.

info.description: Yuka was a great inspiration at developing the brand, the voice and the ton.

takeaway-1.description: The Android app is available as an APK. It is an ongoing test beta version.

takeaway-2.description: The iOS app is available on TestFlight. It is an ongoing test beta version:

_jean_bobby_radio.title: @:work._jean_bobby_radio.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_jean_bobby_radio.shortDescription: iObeya internal and participatory web radio
_jean_bobby_radio.description: Before the COVID-19 pandemic, with my teammate in the UX team, we were used to listen to our Spotify collaborative playlist. A batch of various masterpieces from different personalities. There are some 90's hits: Trip Hop, Alternative rock, House‚Ä¶ Some 80's hits: Goth, New Wave‚Ä¶ Around 500 tracks we listened to everyday. And yet, a virus has co me, and the remote work was the new order. We were distributed. The problem is we cannot use Spotify as a web radio, in order to listen together to our music and react on it. Make our own web radio allows us to retrieve this office atmosphere: Jean-Bobby Radio.

misc.objectives: Listening together to our Spotify collaborative playlist, Retrieving the office atmosphere
misc.roles: Defining the web radio back-end architecture, Creating a graphic universe around our company's mascot, Designing a simple web player and declining the universe through it, Developing and maintaining the web player

part-1.title: Let's start the broadcasting system
part-1.paragraph-1: TBuild a web radio from scratch is not as easy as expected. The challenge was interesting because a web radio is a complex system where each component is connected to broadcast audio to whom wants to listen to. To explain a bit, the audio is played from a classic computer, then it is encoded and sent to a broadcasting server, and finally, the audio can be played from a player.
part-1.caption-1: The web radio system has been designed thanks to a couple of open-source and free solutions as Icecast or Rocket Broadcaster

info.description: This article explains the detailed flow for the most curious

part-2.title: Bring the motion design at the front-stage
part-2.paragraph-1: The web player gathers few actions: Play/Pause, Volume, Now playing information and notifications, the collaborative playlist and the sound folder link, some information about the project and a feedback zone. The middle of the stage is the most important part of the player: the looping animation.
part-2.caption-1: Around the edge are the player's controls, to get more space at the middle of the stage: Jean-Bobby All Around the World.

part-3.title: Our mascot, All Around the World
part-3.paragraph-1: Jean-Bobby is our company's mascot. We are used to get him during our trips or events. He has become a running gag because a lot a people liked to take him on holidays. Jean-Bobby has seen the beauty of our world while being the heart of iObeya (ex-KAP IT).
part-3.paragraph-2: This animated loop is a tribute to this period. The best pictures have been a great inspiration and have been compiled into one short animation.
part-3.caption-1: This animation has been a great opportunity at using Lottie to generate a web-compliant animation. From an Adobe After Effects composition to an animated SVG.

takeaway-1.description: The radio can be played on demand

takeaway-2.description: Jean-Bobby Radio is an open-source project. You can take a glance at the source code on Github.

_awesome_ipsums.title: @:work._awesome_ipsums.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_awesome_ipsums.shortDescription: Design team‚Äôs own Lorem Ipsums from a simple Google Spreadsheet
_awesome_ipsums.description: Sketch is an UX tool, using diagrams to build user experiences, interfaces, prototypes, and illustrations‚Ä¶ The tool can be extended with a plugin system. The purpose is to add features, or script actions. The idea of making a more fun Lorem Ipsum tool was a great opportunity to make a Sketch Plugin and understand how it works.

misc.objectives: Allowing the design team to use custom lorem ipsums as fake content, Making the fake content collaborative
misc.roles: Developing the scripts to create/update/sync. the custom lorem ipsums

part-1.title: Welcome to the world of collaborative content
part-1.paragraph-1: Lorem ipsum¬†is often used to simulate content into a designed web page. Nevertheless, there may be some issues:
part-1.paragraph-2:
• It does not make any sense
  • It is quite boring and repetitive
part-1.paragraph-3: Lorem ipsum¬†could be fun, relevant, and fully personalized. A design team can create, collect and reuse his own fake content. How to get this team involved in collecting content?¬†An online spreadsheet, because it is easy to maintain and always up-to-date.
part-1.paragraph-4: Google Spreadsheet is simple to use and collaborative. It can act as a micro-database for micro-projects.
part-1.caption-1: It is possible to create a new text or update one by filling it with a random value from the spreadsheet

part-2.title: How does it work?
part-2.paragraph-1: The workflow is quite simple: Synchronizing the spreadsheet model to Sketch.
part-2.paragraph-2: Then, creating a text from a random content of the spreadsheet. The text is displayed at the center of the current view.
part-2.paragraph-3: Then, creating a text from a random content of the spreadsheet. The text is displayed at the center of the current view.

takeaway-1.description: If you want to test the plugin, you can download the archive file from the project repository (double-click on the plugin file to install it).

takeaway-2.description: Awesome Ipsums is an open-source project. You can take a glance at the source code on Github.

_iobeya_whiteboard.title: @:work._iobeya_whiteboard.shortTitle@:global.separator@:global.author
_iobeya_whiteboard.shortDescription: Go-to-SaaS solution to enhance iObeya virality and deployment
_iobeya_whiteboard.description: The Whiteboarding session is a lite version of  iObeya. Its purpose is to ease the deployment through a company by providing  a simple meeting framework, reinforcing the collaboration and introducing the solution. This feature was an opportunity to revamp the UI, follow a design philosophy, involve the team, and make user tests.

misc.objectives: Easing the solution deployment, Go-to-SaaS, Reinforcing the position of iObeya on Innovation & Creativity sessions
misc.roles: Facilitating workshops by using the design thinking philosophy, Designing the vision, Revamping the UI, Writing the user stories

challenge.title: What is the problem?
challenge.paragraph-1: iObeya is a structured and strict software. The model is a room = a declared team = a project. This model has some limitations:
challenge.paragraph-2:
• Hard to be deployed through a large company
  • Heavy workflow between the requester and the IT service
challenge.paragraph-3: The platform is fully customizable but the users must be declared and allocated by hand. Besides, the license limits the number of users in a room.
challenge.paragraph-4: The strict and heavy users management is a big pain, and we wonder how can we open the app to any user.

part-1.title: Defining several low-fi flows to make stakeholders aligned
part-1.paragraph-1: We needed to validate our assumptions by drafting a first version. First, making stakeholders aligned was a requirement. We started with some business and user outcomes. The main challenge was to open a little bit more the application to external users (a step towards a SaaS solution).
part-1.paragraph-2: We planned 3 stories on the same session: the facilitator, the declared and external participants. First, we did a storymap to draw the three detailed userflows and prioritize their features. This activity involved the PM, UX, and DEV part.
part-1.paragraph-3: The team involvement was a rewarding experience because some of their ideas have unlocked some uncomfortable situation. As a designer, we must facilitate creative meeting and unlock people capability.
part-1.caption-1: The Lean UX is a canvas that gathers business/user outcomes, and the solution to respond to the opportunity.
part-1.caption-2: The userflow is full of comments because every person in the team is involved and encouraged to give feedback. A strong solution is built by a succession of reviews.

part-2.title: An opportunity to think different
part-2.paragraph-1: Make a SaaS solution was a business opportunity to catch more users and let the app viral through a large organization. We planned to revamp the UI because making a clear separation between a classic board and an whiteboard may be necessary (for example: Figma and Figjam).
part-2.paragraph-2: The classic board presents a heavy and dark header, a lot of tools and utilities. A whiteboard has a lighter aspect, to introduce a lite version of the application. The result of this UI revamping is an entire whiteboarding session, animated by 3 users, Pierre (the facilitator), Paul (participant) and Jacqueline (external participant). This concept was a nice opportunity of using the emotional design philosophy.
part-2.paragraph-3: Several prototypes have been created to get the stakeholders' approval. Conclusion, our assumptions have been validated after showing the entire session. The stakeholders thought their problem should be resolved with the whiteboarding session.
part-2.caption-3: This cartography details the interaction between the three users during the whiteboard session

part-3.title: Technical feasibility enters the field
part-3.paragraph-1: The green light is turned on, so we could go deeper in the detailed specs. First, a technical exploration was required because the UI revamping implied front-end changes. Indeed, the application is built with modules and the whiteboarding session is one of them. Nevertheless, a lot of discussions brought us to roll over. In order to deliver quickly the feature, we made some concessions: the lite version of the interface was postponed. Nevertheless, we got to add some soft touches of illustration and animation, to introduce the emotional design.
part-3.paragraph-2: Despite the roll back, the solution responded to the companies' problem: do an activity with any users and outside a room.
part-3.caption-1: The speedy board is the whiteboarding session metaphor
part-3.caption-2: A purged whiteboarding session brings the user to a sad wrinkled paper 404 page
part-3.caption-3: This animation makes a transition between contexts while onboarding the end-user

takeaway-1.description: Extract of the final user flow
